generalInfo:
If you would like to experience life how it is for the locals during your time in Ghana and not just follow the well-trodden tourist routes, then our “Ghana Life” tour is perfect for you. Mixing with the locals at every opportunity and experiencing daily life in this wonderfully welcoming country with our expert local guides, opens doors and experiences that will create memories that last a lifetime. There are so many positives to embrace here and mixing everyday experiences with ancient cultural sites of interest, beautiful beaches, learning about the dark historical past and exceptional flora and fauna makes this the perfect trip of a lifetime.

Our local award-winning guides are experts in the culture, history, birds, butterflies, and wildlife of all the locations we visit in Ghana. Our company are the leading local responsible travel tour operator in the region, travelling with us ensures we give back to all the communities we visit, leaving nothing but positive footprints. To date our company have built 2 separate schools in different locations offering creche, kindergarten and primary school places to over 600 children who previously did not have access to education. Joining one of our tours also benefits habitat and wildlife conservation as we have also established an eco-tourism project protecting Upper Guinea Rainforest and wildlife that includes endangered bird and mammal species. Booking a tour with us will make you a big part of the positive impact our ethical travel projects are making.

dayInfo.description: Arrival and transfer to hotel. This tour offers a unique experience in West Africa, starting with your arrival at Kotoka International Airport Accra. The tour guides will meet you after you leave the terminal after passing through customs, they will take care of you from here. After boarding the vehicle, you'll be transferred to your accommodation in Accra. Most flights arrive in the late evenings, and your experienced guide will offer you Akwaaba (welcome) and brief you on the trip. You can enjoy an evening meal at the hotel restaurant while acclimatising to West Africa. Accommodation-In Accra

Makola Market, Artist Alliance Gallery, Fantasy Coffins, Kwame Nkrumah Mausoleum and Jamestown Community The Makola Market in Accra offers a vibrant atmosphere for locals to shop and enjoy street foods, including Ghanaian herbal remedies, traditional cloth, jewelry, food, mobile phones, televisions, and sound systems. The bustling market provides an insight into daily life for locals who trade or shop there seven days a week. The Artist Alliance Gallery on the beachfront in Accra is an ideal location to experience traditional and contemporary art and artifacts from all over Ghana and neighboring countries. The "Fantasy Coffins" of Teshie Nungua are a must-see attraction, with various designs available for burial. Ghanaians believe that the departed move on into another world, and the coffins made here may represent the occupation of the deceased or something important to them, from cars, cocoa pods, cigarette packets and airplanes to crocodiles, shoes, bottles of beer and boats to mention a few. You can also visit their workshop and meet the coffin makers. In the afternoon, we pass by Black Star Square, which houses the independence monument, and continue to Independence Square, where we find the enclosed flame of African liberation lit by Kwame Nkrumah himself in 1961. The Kwame Nkrumah Memorial Park, is the final resting place of Ghana's founder and features an adjoining museum with photos, artifacts, and insights into his life. As we head downtown to Jamestown, we enjoy a walking tour of the old community, taking in historical structures that predate the colonial era. The locals are committed to conserving these buildings, giving us an excellent idea of what it was like during the colonial era. Jamestown, a neighborhood in Accra, is known for its rich history and cultural heritage. The area is home to the 30-meter-high lighthouse built by the British in 1871 and colorful fishing boats on the beach. Fort James, built by the British in 1673, was later joined by the Dutch Fort Crêvecoeur and the Danish Fort Christiansborg.These areas give us a perfect picture of old Accra, distinguishing between British Accra and Dutch Accra. The area is known for its Brazilian stone houses, built by free enslaved Africans who migrated back to Africa after the slave trade was abolished. This part of Accra is one of the poorest and there are many social issues within this community. Street children, orphans and child workers are common here and our evening will be dedicated to meeting locals who are trying to change the lives of the youth through boxing. Jamestown is known for producing several World Champion Boxers, including Isaac Dogboe, David Kotei, Joseph Agbeko, Richard Commey, and Azumah Nelson, considered Africa's greatest ever boxer. The youth in this area see boxing as an opportunity for a better life in the future, and they see it as a way to improve their lives. We can visit one of the many gyms in the area to witness the youth and professionals in training. A local street bar and restaurant in the heart of the community provides a comfortable and enjoyable experience for visitors. Accommodation – In Accra

Krobo Traditional Beads and Wli Waterfalls Krobo is the first location we will visit this morning on our way to the Volta Region of Ghana. The Krobo people of Ghana are known for their traditional bead jewelry, which is a symbol of wealth and beauty in the country.that dates back centuries and it would be wonderful to see and learn firsthand the historical importance of beads and learn the ancient process used to make them. We will visit a family compound to learn the process of making beads, which are still worn by most Ghanaian women daily, and are a symbol of wealth and beauty. Our journey continues to the Volta Region of Ghana, we cross the White Volta River, we will head towards Wli, where we will stop for lunch at a restaurant overlooking the stunning river. After lunch, we will head to Wli, where we will check into our accommodation. We will then head to the Wli Falls, believed to be the highest waterfall in West Africa, located in the Agumatsa wildlife sanctuary, surrounded by beautiful flora and fauna. The falls are situated in an idyllic setting, with a colony of Straw-coloured Fruit Bats on the adjacent cliffs and the powerful river flow. We can relax, explore the waterfalls and enjoy a paddle in the pool beneath the waterfall. If you're feeling fit, you can hike to the upper falls before returning to your accommodation for an evening of relaxation. Accommodation-In Wli

Hiking Mount Afajato and Tafi Atome Monkey Sanctuary The morning begins with a hike to Ghana's highest mountain, Mount Afajato, at an elevation of approximately 885 meters. Our guides, experts in butterflies, birds, and Ghana's flora and fauna, share the exceptional nature of this part of Ghana. The afternoon is spent with the locals from the village of Tafi Atome, a community that protects a population of endangered True Mona monkeys. The community perceives the monkeys as sacred messengers from the gods and has been protecting them and their habitat for over 200 years. The local guide explains the history behind their protection and the medicinal plants grown in the surrounding forests. The local ethnic group here are Ewe. We return to the White Volta and check into our accommodation set on the banks of the river, Akosombo to relax for the evening after an action-placed day. Accommodation – In Akosombo

Aburi Botanical Gardens, Koforidua Beads Market and Kumasi The journey to Kumasi begins with breakfast and a visit to the beautiful Akuapem hills, where the Aburi botanical gardens are located. Established in 1890, the gardens offer stunning views of Accra and Tema. The guide will guide you through the gardens, identifying indigenous and exotic flora, including rare butterflies and birds. A short distance from the gardens is the Aburi craft village, where traditional African drums, sculptures, and other crafts have been carved for generations. The prices in this village are among the lowest in Ghana, making it an ideal spot to pick up souvenirs. Your guide will talk you through the meaning and local beliefs connected to many of the sculptures that have been made the same way throughout history. After lunch, we head to Koforidua, the capital of the Eastern Region of Ghana. Koforidua is famous for its traditional bead market, where traders sell local beads, some antique and others newer designs, all at reasonable prices. After mixing with the locals at the market, we continue our journey to Kumasi, home of the Asantehene, King of the powerful Ashanti empire. Upon arrival, we check into our hotel, enjoying the remainder of the day free leisure time. Accommodation – In Kumasi

Ancient Kente and Adinkra villages and West Africa’s largest Market Today, we explore the rich history of local cloth designs and meet new young vibrant designers. Our journey begins in the ancient villages of Adanwomasie and Ntonso, where we learn about the history behind the many designs and interact with skilled weavers who have been weaving kente cloth for generations.Former US President Bill Clinton has had a design named after him called the “Clinton Kente” as Ghanaians were so impressed with the respect, he showed our nation during his state visit to Ghana when he was in office. We visit the village to purchase quality kente cloth at exceptionally low prices before heading to Ntunso, where adinkra cloth and symbols originate. These traditional symbols are carved from calabash shells and printed onto traditional cloth using natural dyes made from the bark of certain local trees. Adinkra cloth has been adorned by the Ashanti's for over four centuries and pre-dates kente cloth. During our time in Ntunso, we learn the meanings behind the various symbols and can make our own strip of adinkra cloth using symbols with personal significance. Women in Ghana from the Ashanti region are famous for being hard working and excellent entrepreneurs. Many big businesses in Kumasi are owned by women, and we visit a successful local restaurant, Jofel, which sells a wide variety of local and international dishes. After lunch, we head to Adum, the commercial center of Kumasi, where most Ghanaians shop. Our afternoon is dedicated to exploring Adum and walking down to Kejetia market, the largest outdoor market in West Africa. The market is a labyrinth of stalls nestled closely together, offering a glimpse into everyday life for the locals living in Kumasi. In the evening, we can rest at our accommodation or head into town to experience local nightlife and music. Accommodation-In Kumasi

Manhyia Palace and Village Life The Manhyia Palace, home to the Asantehene King of the Ashanti's, offers a fascinating excursion through the history and culture of this powerful tribe. The palace Museum provides first-hand insight into the legacies of the Ashanti's and allows visitors to understand their culture during their time in the region. After departing Kumasi, we head south to the villages of Bonkro and Breku, where most Ghanaians live as subsistence farmers. Our company has a strong connection with these communities, working with them to protect their surrounding upper guinea rainforest and endangered bird and mammal species. We have built a school for almost 300 children living in these villages, who previously did not attend school or had to walk 6km each way to the nearest alternative. Our aim was to connect the communities to the conservation of their environment through ethical tourism. In return, we built a school, accommodation, and a restaurant for them to sell food and drinks. All monies generated from this initiative go 100% into a community fund we have established for them. After getting to know the children, we visit the local representative for Kuapa Kokoo Cooperative, a Fair-Trade organization that ensures its members get a good price. Divine chocolate, one of the fastest growing chocolate brands in the world, is likely from Kuapa Kokoo farmers, who own 44% of Divine chocolate. When eating a bar of Divine chocolate, you will see a photograph and information on one of the Ghanaian farmers and their families who grow the cocoa and sell it to Divine through Kuapa Kokoo. They also work hard to promote women in business. This is where the chocolate process starts, visitors can learn about cooperatives improving working conditions, banning child labor, and ensuring women's voices are heard. They can visit local cocoa farms to witness the harvesting process, learn about children using unripe cocoa as sweets, and how cocoa pods are used for soap production. The evening is spent with the community, relaxing at their accommodation, and enjoying a meal while experiencing village life in this remote part of Ghana. Accommodation-In Bonkro

Community life, markets, and local cooking lessons An early start to community life with local markets and cooking lessons. Participants will learn to prepare local dishes and choose their favorite dishes from the local cuisine. After breakfast, they will head to the local markets to purchase ingredients for dinner. This immersion in daily life allows participants to experience life as a local by mixing in the markets, bartering for produce, and returning to their village to prepare a local meal. Lunch will be served at a local chop bar, where the chefs will provide a full list of ingredients and enough money to buy them at the market. Our chef will also give you advice on other dishes during your time cooking together. If cooking lessons are not your interest, there are other opportunities to get involved in the community. They can help with reforestation projects, maintenance of a local school, and developing gardens. Other options include assisting locals in producing Gari, harvesting cassava from a local farm, and learning how to prepare it for sale at the local market. Additionally, they can assist in the extraction process of palm oil, which is used locally for various dishes. The evening meal is enjoyed around an open bonfire, listening to local stories and music, and mixing with the community. Accommodation-In Bonkro

Cape Coast Castle, Baobab Foundation and Batik After breakfast in the village, we bid farewell to our new friends in the community and set off Southwards towards Elmina in the central region of Ghana. The town of Elmina was given its name by the Portuguese due to the abundance of Gold found in Ghana, translated Elmina means The Mine. Gold is of such importance to Ghana today and historically that we were even known as the Gold Coast before independence. Ghana’s gold is of the highest quality and we are the 8th largest exporter in the world and second largest exporter in Africa behind South Africa. Assin Manso, a town in central Ghana, is a significant stop along the enslaved African trade routes. The town is located around the Ndonkor Nsuo, a river where enslaved Africans were checked for fitness and bathed before being transported to Cape Coast for shipment to the Americas. The slaves would have walked hundreds of kilometers through thick forests in shackles and chains, many in poor health. Once bathed and rested, they would continue the final 32-mile march to the dungeons of Cape Coast Castle, where they would remain for up to 6 weeks before being shipped to the Americas. In 1998, a symbolic gesture was made when the bodies of two free (previously enslaved) Africans, Samuel Carson from New York U.S.A. and Crystal from Kingston Jamaica, were returned to Cape Coast Castle and symbolically passed through the "Door of no Return" before being transported to Assin Manso for re-internment. After visiting the river, we make our way to Cape Coast, a world heritage site designated by UNESCO. The castle holds more enslaved Africans captive than any other in West Africa, and visitors can view the dungeons and the infamous "Door of no Return." The castle features a historical museum, a souvenir shop selling literature on Ghana's forts and castles, and a souvenir shop selling literature on Ghana's cultural history and traditions. This excursion provides an understanding of the recent history of Ghana. The fishing communities surrounding the castle are some of the poorest in Cape Coast, many children sleep on the streets, do not attend school and girls become very vulnerable as they have no safe place to stay. Our lunch today will be taken at a wonderful organization in this community that is giving these children hope of a better future. The Baobab Children Foundation is a non-formal vocational school in the poor fishing communities surrounding the castle in Cape Coast, focusing on helping children who have not attended school, left school early, or have disabilities. The foundation offers a wide selection of health-conscious dishes and a shop where visitors can purchase items made by children trained at the Baobab vocational school, from Batik dresses, bead jewelry, organic creams, bags, kente weavings, rings, postcards, paintings and potter. All proceeds go back into supporting the foundation. In the afternoon, visitors can immerse themselves in true African art during a traditional batik making workshop with Global Mamas, an organization that empowers local women to learn artistic skills and sell their finished products in the fair-trade market. By working side by side with local artisans, visitors can learn traditional techniques of batik making and production, such as wax heating, stamping, and drying. After a day of varied experiences, including exploring the tropical forests of inland Ghana and the beautiful coastal communities, guests can relax at beachfront accommodation in Brenu Akyinim. Accommodation – In Brenu Akyinim

Kakum Rainforest Canopy Walkway, Stingless Bee Center, Palm Wine, Local Gin Distillery and Beach Relaxation An early start awaits as we head to Kakum National Park, a semi-deciduous upper guinea rainforest in Ghana's Cape Coast. This park protects the original habitat and was the local's home and major source of food before becoming a National Park. The walkway consists of seven bridges attached to seven emerging trees, 40 meters above the rainforest floor. The information centre offers breathtaking views and an informative information centre about the park's flora and fauna. Over 40 different mammal species have been recorded within the park, including forest elephants, leopards, and six primate species. On the border of the forest, the International Stingless Bee Project is located nearby, with approximately 9 species identified in Ghana. The project educates visitors about the importance of bees locally, their medicinal qualities, and their importance to the eco system. The park also features a stingless bee walkway and butterfly garden where many forest butterfly species feed. The surrounding habitat outside the forest is mainly palm plantations and cocoa farms, which are having a devastating effect on rainforest habitats. Palm oil is found in almost 50% of products sold globally, and most of these companies are in developing poor countries where they can exploit locals and have less restrictions on habitat destruction. Cocoa farms are better for the environment, as they yield better harvests if indigenous tree species are planted alongside them within the farm. Ghanaians have several traditional uses for the palm tree, and visiting a local farm will provide firsthand insight into why locally palm is so popular. A common sight in Ghana is locals tapping palm trees for palm wine, a low, popular alcoholic drink. Once a palm plantation is matured, farmers sell the trees to distillers who produce palm wine, a local low alcoholic drink of around 3% proof. The main income from the tree comes from distilling Akpeteshi, a local hard gin of varying strengths, believed to be around 70% proof. The name Akpeteshi translates to "kill me quick." We stop for lunch at Han's cottage Botel near Kakum, built over a lake containing Nile crocodiles and surrounded by tropical guinea rainforest. After lunch, we relax at our accommodation in Brenu Akyinim, located on one of Ghana's finest beachfront locations. Accommodation-In Brenu Akyinim

Brenu Akyinim Community, Nzulezu Still Village and Ankasa Reserve After breakfast on the beach front, we head west towards the Ivory Coast border and Ankasa Reserve. Our accommodation is less than a 5-minute walk away, providing an opportunity to visit the local community and one of the schools our company has built through responsibly minded travelers like yourselves when you book through us. This is a great opportunity to meet the children you are helping and give back to communities in need. After meeting the children, we set off towards Ankasa Reserve, where we will reach Beyin for lunch before heading through the beautiful Amasuri wetlands in traditional dugout canoe to find the Nzulezu Stilt Village. Legend has it that the community migrated from Watala part of the ancient Ghanaian Empire 600 years ago after being driven from their homes during conflict. They built their homes over the lake for additional protection, and the snail is now sacred to this community. The main occupation of the community is farmers, not fishermen as expected. The boat ride on the wetlands is a major highlight, as they are now recognized as globally important wetlands for birds. The afternoon boat ride, and meeting the local community are highlights. Ankasa Reserve, connected to the Nini-Suhien National Park, protects over 500 square kilometers of mostly pristine wet evergreen upper guinea rainforest. This habitat played an important role in the life of Ghanaians historically, as it was their main source of water and food. By far Ghana's finest remaining rainforest habitat, it protects many endangered mammals and is home to many wonderful birds and wildlife. On our arrival we check into our accommodation and there will be an option for a night walk inside the forest. Alternatively, you can relax at your accommodation. Accommodation-In Ankasa

Biking and Hiking at Ankasa Reserve, Bamboo Cathedral and Village Life A beautiful morning waking up so close to nature near this wonderful forest habitat. The Bamboo Cathedral, located 12 kilometers inside the forest, is a must-see attraction in Ankasa, Ghana. The journey to this remote location can be done by mountain bikes or 4x4 vehicles at the accommodation. Guides are available to identify any birds or mammals during the journey. After a full morning in the forest, lunch is served at the accommodation, where visitors can relax and recharge. The community is mainly subsistence farmers living in basic mud houses, trading their produce at local markets, to enable them to buy items and provide for their families. In the afternoon, visitors can visit the local school and meet with farmers, learning about local delicacies like Gari and FuFu, and visiting the local chop bar or drinking spot is also a highlight and insight into where people meet to socialize. Ghana is the world's second-largest cocoa exporter, with approximately 800,000 tons exported annually. The entire family takes care of the farms, and local soap is also produced from cocoa pods. A relaxed afternoon is spent in the village, with the option to arrange biking or walking trails in the forest to explore wildlife. The evening is spent listening to the sounds of nature at the accommodation. Accommodation-In Ankasa

Ankasa Reserve, Beach Bonfire and Traditional Drumming and Dance On our final morning in Ankasa, we enjoy a relaxed breakfast before heading to our beachfront accommodation in Brenu Akyinim. The afternoon is free to relax on the beach or explore local coastal villages. As the sun sets, we enjoy an evening meal around a bonfire, with a special treat of a local traditional Ghanaian drumming and dance troupe performing on the beach. This evening offers an opportunity to learn the basics of drumming and showcase our moves while overlooking the beautiful gold coast of West Africa. This unforgettable experience is a perfect way to spend the evening. Accommodation-In Brenu Akyinim

Elmina Markets, Boat Builders and Departure This morning we check out of our accommodation and set off back towards Accra. The morning is spent exploring Elmina fishing town, a vibrant community known for its traditional wooden boats. The community's fishing boats, which have not changed in centuries, nor the tools used to make them. A sight to behold. The colorful boats bring their daily catch into the harbour, providing an enjoyable atmosphere for the locals. As we continue towards Accra, we stop at Winneba for lunch. Upon arrival, we may have time to visit the Accra Mall, where we can learn about modern Ghana and purchase souvenirs. Our early evening meal at a locally owned restaurant offers an excellent selection of local and international dishes, providing an opportunity to say goodbye and reflect on the experience. Our team will then transfer you to the airport for your departure, ensuring a memorable experience in Ghana. Departure
